column4: Anonymous or real identity of flaw reporter

column3: Unique flaw report ID. The flaw report ID can be referenced in future submissions or mitigation efforts, similar to vulnerability identifiers such as CVE identifiers in computer security (Cybersecurity and Infrastructure Security Agency, 2022).
AI system(s) and version(s) involved; multiple systems can be selected

Current status of the report, recorded with timestamps as updated by the submitter or receiving company. Initially, the status of a report is “Submitted”, but once it is submitted the status field will be updated to reflect current status of addressing the flaw (e.g., “Under investigation” or “Fixed”) (Cybersecurity and Infrastructure Security Agency, 2022).
System session ID(s) for tracing flaw environment
Versions of other software or hardware systems involved
Description of the flaw, its identification, reproduction, and how it violates system policies or user expectations

Detail of how the expectations of the system are violated or undocumented, pointing to the terms of use, acceptable use policy, system card, or other documentation. Policies may be explicitly or implicitly violated.
Triage tag with name of system developer
Triage tag with name and version of system
Triage tag with worst-case scenario estimate of how negatively stakeholders will be impacted
Triage tag with rough estimate of how often the flaw might be expressed across system deployments
Triage tag indicating how impacted stakeholders may suffer if the flaw is not addressed
Triage tag(s) indicating who may be harmed if the flaw is not addressed
Triage tag indicating worst-case scenario estimate of how negatively stakeholders will be impacted
Triage tag indicating whether the submitter believes the flaw report meets the criteria for bounty programs

column4: Details on specific real-world event(s) that have occurred

column3: Systems involved in real-world event(s) which generalized flaw reports might cover
How the submitter is related to the event (e.g., “affected stakeholder” or “independent observer”)
Physical; psychological; reputational; economic/property; environmental; public interest/critical infrastructure; fundamental rights; other
Maximum severity of harm experienced in the real world
Justification of why the event constitutes harm and how system flaws contributed to it

column4: Tactics observed or used (e.g., from MITRE's ATLAS Matrix)
How the reporter knows about the security incident, including observation methods
A code and documentation archive proving the existence of a vulnerability

column3: A list of system inputs/outputs to help understand the replication packet
Files evidencing the flaw statistically, including test data, custom evaluators, and structured datasets

column2: Argument supporting sufficient evidence of a flaw
